docs.abstract: New rail initiatives, bolstered by sharp increases in business-travel ridership on Amtrak's Northeast Corridor and on other Amtrak rail corridors in Southern California and Pacific Northwest, are moving along; Railway Age magazine editor William C Vantuono says one of most important is fledgling Midwest Regional Rail Initiative, projected $4.1 billion system to develop high-speed corridors linking Chicago, Detroit, St Louis, Milwaukee and other cities in nine Midwest states; Federal Railroad Administration has announced $3 million grant to Florida High-Speed Rail Authority for studies on high-speed rail link from Orlando to Miami; American Express says business travel is booming in China; American Express has opened its joint venture in Beijing with China International Travel Service; Kroll Inc is affiliating one of its businesses with iJet Travel Intelligence, Web and wireless travel intelligence provider for corporate travelers; two companies will leverage their technological and analytical operations to provide travel advisories to combined international customer base of 170 clients; British Airways drops price of ticket on supersonic Concorde from New York to London to $6,999, drop of 45 percent from regular price, for selected travel days through Aug 31; other options noted (M)
docs.snippet: Rail Initiatives Are Moving Along      The automobile and airline industries, both heavily subsidized by taxpayers, have ''brainwashed'' business travelers into supposing that viable intercity passenger rail service is an unlikely prospect in the Un
docs.lead_paragraph: Rail Initiatives Are Moving Along The automobile and airline industries, both heavily subsidized by taxpayers, have ''brainwashed'' business travelers into supposing that viable intercity passenger rail service is an unlikely prospect in the United States, argues William C. Vantuono, the editor of Railway Age magazine. Nevertheless, new rail initiatives, bolstered by the sharp increases in business-travel ridership on Amtrak's Northeast Corridor and on other Amtrak rail corridors in Southern California and the Pacific Northwest, are moving along.

docs.abstract: China demands that South Korea hand over several North Korean migrants holed up in its embassy in Beijing, asserting they have no legal right to asylum (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Toughening On Migrants

docs.snippet: China demanded that South Korea hand over several North Korean migrants holed up in its embassy in Beijing and asserted that they had no legal right of asylum. Seoul is under domestic pressure to support such refugees in their quest to reach South Ko
docs.lead_paragraph: China demanded that South Korea hand over several North Korean migrants holed up in its embassy in Beijing and asserted that they had no legal right of asylum. Seoul is under domestic pressure to support such refugees in their quest to reach South Korea, and diplomats said there could be a lengthy standoff. Last Thursday and Friday, a single man and a couple from North Korea dashed past guards to the embassy, and on Monday another man got inside, diplomats said. The growing stream of North Koreans seeking refuge in foreign embassies has posed a quandary for Beijing, which treats North Korea as an ally and has formally agreed to repatriate such migrants. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

docs.abstract: South Korean Foreign Ministry rejects China's demands to surrender four North Koreans seeking asylum in South Korean embassy in Beijing (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: China Rebuffed On Refugees

docs.snippet: The Foreign Ministry rejected China's demands to surrender four North Koreans who have sought asylum in the South Korean embassy in Beijing. It said saying China should treat them as it had 38 North Korean refugees who have recently entered embassies
docs.lead_paragraph: The Foreign Ministry rejected China's demands to surrender four North Koreans who have sought asylum in the South Korean embassy in Beijing. It said saying China should treat them as it had 38 North Korean refugees who have recently entered embassies or consulates of other countries and were permitted to leave China. Don Kirk (NYT)

docs.abstract: Hong Kong annual candlelight vigil to remember protesters killed by Chinese military in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989 draws sparser crowd than usual this year; poll by group with reputation for impartiality finds that more than half of Hong Kong's population is satisfied with Beijing's rule of China and, separately, with Beijing's handling of Hong Kong affairs (M)

headline.main: Hong Kong Passions About Tiananmen Seem to Be Fading

docs.snippet: Maybe it was the recession, maybe it was the government's toughening stance toward critics or maybe it was just competition from the World Cup, but the annual candlelight vigil here to remember the protesters killed by the Chinese military in Tiananm
docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the recession, maybe it was the government's toughening stance toward critics or maybe it was just competition from the World Cup, but the annual candlelight vigil here to remember the protesters killed by the Chinese military in Tiananmen Square in Beijing drew a sparser crowd than usual tonight. Organizers estimated the crowd at 45,000 people, down slightly from their estimate of 50,000 last year. The police, who have come up with slightly smaller estimates than the organizers for previous vigils, said only 12,000 people showed up tonight. While the police did not release their methods, calculations based on the density of the crowd and the space it filled indicated that the real count was below 20,000.

docs.abstract: Many of 100,000 North Koreans living illegally in China hope to get to South Korea; in last 10 weeks, 38 of them won political asylum in South Korea by jumping over walls or pushing through gates at embassies and consulates in Beijing; four more are now in South Korean Consulate as their passage out is being negotiated; such successes have turned walls of embassies in Beijing into new boundary between divided Koreas; South Korea offers arrivals from North nearly $30,000 in resettlement aid; experts on North Korea predict that desperate dashes will increase, but many people who work with refugees worry that news-making asylum ploys may actually increase harassment for North Koreans who remain illegally in China; photos (M)

headline.main: Defying Crackdown, North Koreans Stream Into China

docs.snippet: Late last month a young North Korean conducted reconnaissance in Beijing's embassy district, once a serene tree-lined oasis of stately buildings, now laced with barbed wire and dotted with roadblocks.    ''I still think I could get in,'' concluded th
docs.lead_paragraph: Late last month a young North Korean conducted reconnaissance in Beijing's embassy district, once a serene tree-lined oasis of stately buildings, now laced with barbed wire and dotted with roadblocks. ''I still think I could get in,'' concluded the wiry man in a red T-shirt, who would give only his surname, Han. One of the more than 100,000 North Koreans living illegally in China, Mr. Han now has the goal of moving to South Korea.

docs.abstract: Photo of Volkswagen Polo at Beijing international auto show; VW has sold 186,000 Polos in China in first five months of 2002

headline.main: Picture Mao In a VW Polo

docs.snippet: Photo of Volkswagen Polo at Beijing international auto show; VW has sold 186,000 Polos in China in first five months of 2002

docs.abstract: Chinese police scuffle with South Korean diplomats when two North Korean asylum-seekers try to enter consulate in Beijing; event caps three weeks of increasing tensions at consulate, which now has 18 North Korean asylum seekers stuck inside; similar stalemate persists at Canadian Embassy, where fate of two North Koreans is still under negotiation; photo (M)

headline.main: Tensions Mount With Clash Over North Korean Asylum Seeker

docs.snippet: Tensions ran high today as Chinese police officers scuffled with South Korean diplomats here in a dispute over an asylum seeker from North Korea.    At 11 this morning, two North Koreans entered the South Korean Consulate here seeking political asylu
docs.lead_paragraph: Tensions ran high today as Chinese police officers scuffled with South Korean diplomats here in a dispute over an asylum seeker from North Korea. At 11 this morning, two North Koreans entered the South Korean Consulate here seeking political asylum. They were pursued by Chinese security personnel, who caught and detained one, a middle-aged man, and removed him from the consulate.

docs.abstract: Beijing Mayor Liu Qi orders all Internet cafes in city closed temporarily after at least 24 die in fire in unlicensed cafe in university district; fire is said to be deadliest in city in more than 50 years (M)

headline.main: Beijing Mayor Cracks Down on Internet Cafes After Fatal Fire

docs.snippet: The mayor of Beijing ordered all Internet cafes in the city today to shut down temporarily after at least 24 died in an early-morning fire in an unlicensed cafe in the university district.     The fire, said to be the deadliest here in more than 50 y
docs.lead_paragraph: The mayor of Beijing ordered all Internet cafes in the city today to shut down temporarily after at least 24 died in an early-morning fire in an unlicensed cafe in the university district. The fire, said to be the deadliest here in more than 50 years, started at 2:40 a.m. in the Lanjisu Internet cafe in northwestern Beijing. Like many similar establishments, the Internet cafe was crowded with students who cannot afford personal computers and visit the cafes at night to take advantage of lower rates as they surf the Web, play Internet games, dawdle in chat rooms and exchange e-mail.

docs.abstract: Two more North Koreans sneak into South Korean Consulate in Beijing, seeking political asylum (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: More North Koreans Seek Asylum

docs.snippet: Two more North Koreans sneaked into the South Korean Consulate in Beijing, seeking political asylum in Seoul. There are now 20 asylum seekers stuck inside, their fate in dispute. South Korea says they should be allowed to decide where they want to li
docs.lead_paragraph: Two more North Koreans sneaked into the South Korean Consulate in Beijing, seeking political asylum in Seoul. There are now 20 asylum seekers stuck inside, their fate in dispute. South Korea says they should be allowed to decide where they want to live; China, bound to return asylum seekers under a treaty with North Korea, insists the North Koreans should be turned over to its police. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

docs.abstract: Beijing officials arrest two teenage boys charged with intentionally setting fire that killed 24 people in unlicensed Internet cafe (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Arrests In Cafe Fire

docs.snippet: Officials in Beijing said two teenage boys had been arrested for intentionally setting the fire that killed 24 people last weekend in an unlicensed Internet cafe. The boys, who were identified only by their surnames as Zhang, 13, and Song, 14, were d
docs.lead_paragraph: Officials in Beijing said two teenage boys had been arrested for intentionally setting the fire that killed 24 people last weekend in an unlicensed Internet cafe. The boys, who were identified only by their surnames as Zhang, 13, and Song, 14, were detained Tuesday and have confessed to setting the fire out of revenge after a dispute with staff members, the city government said in a statement. The disaster led Beijing's mayor to order the temporary closure of the estimated 2,400 cybercafes in the city, all but 200 of which are unlicensed. Erik Eckholm (NYT)
